November&nbsp;29, 2001, we terminated our commodity derivative contracts with ENA. We exercised our rights pursuant to the early termination provisions of such contracts as a result
of ENA's bankruptcy filing and related events. We believe that we had the legal right to terminate these agreements, but ENA may challenge our termination in bankruptcy court. Applying the
mark-to-market and setoff methodology of our contracts with ENA, we have calculated that we owed ENA a net amount of $204,000 for all derivative transactions that were
outstanding under our ENA contracts. Although we believe this methodology was correct, it is possible that ENA will challenge our calculations and claim larger amounts are owed. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have also terminated our production sales contracts with ENA and its affiliates, except for an ongoing month-to-month sales arrangement with EOTT Energy
Partners, L.P., a publicly traded entity owned in part by Enron Corp. EOTT currently supports its payment obligations to us by posting letters of credit. We continue to monitor EOTT's credit condition
closely and will take appropriate action should it deteriorate. We believe that our exposure to potential loss for payment on production delivered to Enron affiliates is less than $1.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploration is a high-risk activity. The seismic data and other advanced technologies we use are expensive and cannot
eliminate exploration risks.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our oil and natural gas operations are subject to the economic risks typically associated with drilling exploratory wells. In conducting exploration activities,
we may drill unsuccessful wells and experience losses and, if oil and natural gas are discovered, there is no assurance that such oil and natural gas can be economically produced or satisfactorily
marketed. There can be no assurance that new wells we drill will be productive or that we will recover all or any portion of our investment. The presence of unanticipated pressure or irregularities in
formations, miscalculations or accidents may cause our exploration activities to be unsuccessful, resulting in a total loss of our investment in such activities. The cost of drilling, completing and
operating wells is often uncertain. Our drilling operations may be curtailed, delayed or canceled as a result of numerous factors, many of which may be beyond our control, including unexpected
drilling conditions, title problems, weather conditions, compliance with environmental and other governmental requirements and shortages or delays in the delivery of equipment and services. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=19,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=184523,FOLIO='17',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DI1331A.;16',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;19:38' -->
</FONT></P>

<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dk1331_1_18"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We rely to a significant extent on seismic data and other advanced technologies in conducting our exploration activities. Even when used and properly interpreted, seismic data and
visualization techniques only assist geoscientists in identifying subsurface structures and hydrocarbon indicators. Such data is not conclusive in determining if hydrocarbons are present or
economically producible. The use of seismic data and other technologies also requires greater pre-drilling expenditures than traditional drilling strategies. We could incur losses as a
result of these expenditures. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Failure to replace reserves may negatively affect our business.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our future success depends upon our ability to find, develop or acquire additional oil and natural gas reserves that are economically recoverable. Our proved
reserves generally decline when reserves are produced, unless we conduct successful exploration or development activities or acquire properties containing proved reserves, or both. We may not be able
to find, develop or acquire additional reserves on an economic basis. Furthermore, while our revenues may increase if oil and natural gas prices increase significantly, our finding costs for
additional reserves could also increase. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Reserve estimates are inherently uncertain. Any material inaccuracies in our reserve estimates or assumptions underlying our reserve
estimates, such as the discount rate used, could cause the quantities and net present value of our reserves to be overstated.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There are numerous uncertainties inherent in estimating quantities of proved reserves, including many factors beyond our control, that could cause the quantities
and net present value of our reserves to be overstated. The reserve information set forth in this report represents estimates based on reports prepared or audited by independent petroleum engineers
and prepared by our internal engineers. Reserve engineering is not an exact science. Estimates of economically recoverable oil and natural gas reserves and of future net cash flows necessarily depend
upon a number of variable factors and assumptions, any of which may cause these estimates to vary considerably from actual results, such as: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>historical
production from the area compared with production from other producing areas;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>assumed
effects of regulation by governmental agencies;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>assumptions
concerning future oil and natural gas prices;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>assumptions
regarding future operating costs;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>estimates
of future severance and excise taxes;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>assumptions
regarding capital expenditures; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>estimates
regarding workover and remedial costs. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Estimates
of reserves based on risk of recovery and estimates of expected future net cash flows prepared or audited by different engineers, or by the same engineers at different times,
may vary substantially. Actual production, revenues and expenditures with respect to our reserves will likely vary from estimates, and the variance may be material. The net present values referred to
in this report should not be construed as the current market value of the estimated oil and natural gas reserves attributable to our properties. In accordance with requirements of the United States
Securities and Exchange Commission, or SEC, the estimated discounted net cash flows from proved reserves are generally based on prices and costs as of the date of the estimate, whereas actual future
prices and costs may be materially higher or lower. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Competition in our industry is intense, and many of our competitors have greater financial, technological and other resources than we
have.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We operate in the highly competitive areas of oil and natural gas exploitation, exploration and acquisition. The oil and natural gas industry is characterized by
rapid and significant technological
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=20,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=44522,FOLIO='18',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DK1331A.;14',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='18-MAR-2002;18:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1331_1_19"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
advancements and introductions of new products and services using new technologies. We face intense competition from major and independent oil and natural gas companies in each of the following
areas: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>seeking
to acquire desirable producing properties or new leases for future exploration;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>marketing
our oil and natural gas production;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>integrating
new technologies; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>acquiring
the personnel, equipment and expertise necessary to develop and operate our properties. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Many
other companies have financial, technological and other resources substantially greater than our own. These companies may be able to pay more for exploratory prospects and
productive oil and natural gas properties and may be able to define, evaluate, bid for and purchase a greater number of properties and prospects than our financial or human resources permit. Further,
many of our competitors may enjoy technological advantages over us and may be able to implement new technologies more rapidly than we can. Our ability to explore for oil and natural gas and to acquire
additional properties in the future will depend upon our ability to successfully conduct operations, implement advanced technologies, evaluate and select suitable properties and consummate
transactions in this highly competitive environment. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are subject to complex laws and regulations, including environmental and safety regulations, that can adversely affect the cost, manner
or feasibility of doing business.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operations and facilities are subject to certain Federal, state and local laws and regulations relating to the exploration for, and the development,
production and transportation of, oil and natural gas, as well as environmental and safety matters. Although we believe that we are in substantial compliance with all applicable laws and regulations,
we cannot be certain that existing laws or regulations, as currently interpreted or reinterpreted in the future, or future laws or regulations will not harm our business, results of operations and
financial condition. We may be required to make large and unanticipated capital expenditures to comply with environmental and other governmental regulations, such as: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>land
use restrictions;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>drilling
bonds and other financial responsibility requirements;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>spacing
of wells;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>unitization
and pooling of properties;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>habitat
and endangered species protection, reclamation and remediation, and other environmental protection;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>safety
precautions;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>operational
reporting; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>taxation.
</FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Under
these laws and regulations, we could be liable for: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>personal
injuries;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>property
and natural resource damages;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>oil
spills and releases or discharges of hazardous materials;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>well
reclamation costs; </FONT><P><FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=21,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=950391,FOLIO='19',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DK1331A.;14',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='18-MAR-2002;18:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1331_1_20"> </A></FONT></P>

</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>remediation
and clean-up costs and other governmental sanctions, such as fines and penalties; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>other
environmental damages. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
could also experience significant delays in operations on our properties, inability to develop particular properties, or significantly increased costs of operations as a result of
regulatory
requirements or restrictions. We are unable to predict the ultimate cost of compliance with these requirements or their effect on our operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We cannot control activities on properties we do not operate. Inability to fund our capital expenditures may result in reduction or
forfeiture of our interests in some of our non-operated projects.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other companies operate approximately 30% of the net present value of our reserves and we have limited ability to exercise influence over operations for these
properties or their associated costs. Our dependence on the operator and other working interest owners for these projects and our limited ability to influence operations and associated costs could
prevent the realization of our targeted returns on capital in drilling or acquisition activities. The success and timing of drilling and exploitation activities on properties operated by others,
therefore, depend upon a number of factors that will be outside our control, including: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>timing
and amount of capital expenditures;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
operator's expertise and financial resources;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>approval
of other participants in drilling wells; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>selection
of technology. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Where
we are not the majority owner or operator of a particular oil and natural gas project, we may have no control over the timing or amount of capital expenditures associated with such
project. If we are not willing to fund our capital expenditures relating to such projects when required by the majority owner or operator, our interests in these projects may be reduced or forfeited. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our business involves many operating risks that may result in substantial losses. Insurance may be unavailable or inadequate to protect us
against these risks.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operations are subject to hazards and risks inherent in drilling for, producing and transporting oil and natural gas, such as: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>fires;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>natural
disasters;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>explosions;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>formations
with abnormal pressures;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>casing
collapses;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>embedded
oilfield drilling and service tools;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>uncontrollable
flows of underground natural gas, oil and formation water;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>surface
cratering;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>pipeline
ruptures or cement failures; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>environmental
hazards such as natural gas leaks, oil spills and discharges of toxic gases. </FONT><P><FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=22,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=723859,FOLIO='20',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DK1331A.;14',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='18-MAR-2002;18:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1331_1_21"> </A></FONT></P>

</DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Any
of these risks can cause substantial losses resulting from: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>injury
or loss of life;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>damage
to and destruction of property, natural resources and equipment;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>pollution
and other environmental damage;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>regulatory
investigations and penalties;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>suspension
of operations; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>repair
and remediation costs. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
protection against operating hazards, we maintain insurance coverage against some, but not all, potential losses. However, losses could occur for uninsurable or uninsured risks, or in
amounts in excess of existing insurance coverage. The occurrence of an event that is not fully covered by insurance could harm our financial condition and results of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We are vulnerable to risks associated with operating in the Gulf of Mexico.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operations and financial results could be significantly impacted by conditions in the Gulf of Mexico because we explore and produce extensively in that area.
As a result of this activity, we are vulnerable to the risks associated with operating in the Gulf of Mexico, including those relating to: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>adverse
weather conditions;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>oil
field service costs and availability;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>compliance
with environmental and other laws and regulations;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>remediation
and other costs resulting from oil spills or releases of hazardous materials; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>failure
of equipment or facilities. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, we intend to conduct some of our exploration in the deep waters (greater than approximately 1,000 feet) of the Gulf of Mexico, where operations are more difficult and costly
than in shallower waters. The deep waters in the Gulf of Mexico lack the physical and oilfield service infrastructure present in its shallower waters. As a result, deep water operations may require a
significant amount of time between a discovery and the time that we can market our production, thereby increasing the risk involved with these operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Further,
production of reserves from reservoirs in the Gulf of Mexico generally declines more rapidly than from reservoirs in many other producing regions of the world. This results in
recovery of a relatively higher percentage of reserves from properties in the Gulf of Mexico during the initial few&nbsp;years of production, and as a result, our reserve replacement needs from new
prospects may be greater there than for our operations elsewhere. Also, our revenues and return on capital will depend significantly on prices prevailing during these relatively short production
periods. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We depend upon our management team and our operations require us to attract and retain experienced technical personnel.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The successful implementation of our strategies and handling of other issues integral to our future success will depend, in part, on our experienced management
team. The loss of members of our management team could have an adverse effect on our business. Our exploratory drilling success and the success of other activities integral to our operations will
depend, in part, on our ability to attract and retain experienced explorationists, engineers and other professionals. Competition for experienced explorationists, engineers and some other
professionals is extremely intense. If we cannot retain our technical personnel or attract additional experienced technical personnel, our ability to compete could be harmed.
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=23,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=443649,FOLIO='21',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DK1331A.;14',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='18-MAR-2002;18:30' -->
<A NAME="page_dk1331_1_22"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The marketability of our production depends upon factors over which we may have no control.  </I></B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The marketability of our production depends in part upon the availability, proximity and capacity of pipelines, natural gas gathering systems and processing
facilities. Any significant change in market factors affecting these infrastructure facilities could adversely impact our ability to deliver the oil and natural gas we produce to market in an
efficient manner, which could harm our financial condition and results of operations. We deliver oil and natural gas through gathering systems and pipelines that we do not own. These facilities may
not be available to us in the future. Our ability to produce and market oil and natural gas is affected and may be also harmed by: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Federal
and state regulation of oil and natural gas production;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>transportation,
tax and energy policies;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>changes
in supply and demand; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>general
economic conditions. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our principal stockholders own a significant amount of our common stock, giving them a controlling influence over corporate transactions
and other matters.  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our principal stockholders, including Westport Energy LLC, ERI Investments,&nbsp;Inc., an affiliate of Equitable Resources Corp., and the Belfer Group, a group
of former Belco stockholders, together beneficially own approximately 68.4% of our outstanding common stock. Accordingly, these stockholders, acting together through a shareholders agreement, based on
their current share ownership, are able to control the outcome of the election of directors as well as, if they choose to act together, the adoption or amendment of provisions in our articles of
incorporation or bylaws and the approval of mergers and other significant corporate transactions. These factors may also delay or prevent a change in our management or voting control. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Glossary of Oil and Natural Gas Terms  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following are abbreviations and definitions of certain terms commonly used in the oil and natural gas industry and this report: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;bbl.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One stock tank barrel, or 42 U.S. gallons liquid volume, used in reference to oil or other
liquid hydrocarbons. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;bbl/d.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One stock tank barrel of oil or other liquid hydrocarbons per day. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bcf.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One&nbsp;billion cubic feet of natural gas at standard atmospheric conditions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Bcfe.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One&nbsp;billion cubic feet equivalent of natural gas, calculated by converting oil to
equivalent Mcf at a ratio of 6 Mcf to 1 bbl of oil. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;CO<SUB>2</SUB> Flood.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;A tertiary recovery method in which CO<SUB>2</SUB> is injected into the
reservoir to enhance oil recovery. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Delay Rentals.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Fees paid to the owner of the oil and natural gas lease prior to the commencement of
production. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Developed Acreage.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The number of acres which are allocated or assignable to producing wells or wells
capable of production. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=24,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=684317,FOLIO='22',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DK1331A.;14',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='18-MAR-2002;18:30' -->
</FONT></P>

<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dm1331_1_23"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Development Well.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;A well drilled within or in close proximity to an area of known production
targeting existing reservoirs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploitation.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The continuing development of a known producing formation in a previously discovered
field. To make complete or maximize the ultimate recovery of oil or natural gas from the field by work including development wells, secondary recovery equipment or other suitable processes and
technology. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploration.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The search for natural accumulations of oil and natural gas by any geological,
geophysical or other suitable means. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploratory Well.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;A well drilled either in search of a new and as yet undiscovered accumulation of
oil or natural gas, or with the intent to greatly extend the limits of a pool already partly developed. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross Acres.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The total acres in which we have a working interest. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross Producing Wells.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The total number of producing wells in which we own any amount of working
interest. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Horizontal Drilling.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;A drilling operation in which a portion of the well is drilled horizontally
within a productive or potentially productive formation. This operation usually yields a well which has the ability to produce higher volumes than a vertical well drilled in the same formation. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Injection well or Injection.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;A well which is used to place liquids or gases into the producing zone
during secondary/tertiary recovery operations to assist in maintaining reservoir pressure and enhancing recoveries from the field. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mbbl.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One thousand barrels of oil or other liquid hydrocarbons. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mcf.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One thousand cubic feet of natural gas. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mcfe.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One thousand cubic feet equivalent of natural gas, calculated by converting oil to equivalent
Mcf at a ratio of 6 Mcf to 1 bbl of oil. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mineral Interest.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The property interest that includes the right to enter to explore for, drill for,
produce, store and remove oil and natural gas from the subject lands, or to lease to another for those purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mmbbl.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One&nbsp;million barrels of oil or other liquid hydrocarbons. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mmbtu.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One&nbsp;million British thermal units. One British thermal unit is the amount of heat
required to raise the temperature of one pound of water one degree Fahrenheit. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mmcf.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One&nbsp;million cubic feet of natural gas, measured at standard atmospheric conditions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mmcf/d.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One&nbsp;million cubic feet of natural gas per day. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mmcfe.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One&nbsp;million cubic feet equivalent of natural gas, calculated by converting oil to
equivalent Mcf at a ratio of 6 Mcf to 1 bbl of oil. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mmcfe/d.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One&nbsp;million cubic feet equivalent of natural gas per day, calculated by converting
oil to equivalent Mcf at a ratio of 6 Mcf to 1 bbl of oil.
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=25,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=864034,FOLIO='23',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DM1331A.;15',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:11' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1331_1_24"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net Acres.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross acres multiplied by the percentage working interest owned by us. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net Present Value.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The present value of estimated future revenues to be generated from the production
of proved reserves calculated in accordance with SEC guidelines, net of estimated lease
operating expense, production taxes and future development costs, using prices and costs as of the date of estimation without future escalation, without giving effect to non-property
related expenses such as general and administrative expenses, debt service and depreciation, depletion and amortization, or Federal income taxes and discounted using an annual discount rate of 10%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net Production.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Production that is owned by Westport less royalties and production due others. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Non-operated Working Interest.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The working interest or fraction thereof in a lease or
unit, the owner of which is without operating rights by reason of an operating agreement. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;NYMEX.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;New York Mercantile Exchange. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating Income.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross oil and natural gas revenue less applicable production taxes and lease
operating expense. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operator.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The individual or company responsible for the exploration, exploitation and production of
an oil or natural gas well or lease. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Proved Developed Reserves.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Proved reserves that can be expected to be recovered through existing
wells with existing equipment and operating methods. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Proved Reserves.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The estimated quantities of oil, natural gas and natural gas liquids which
geological and engineering data demonstrate with reasonable certainty to be recoverable in future&nbsp;years from known reservoirs under existing economic and operating conditions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Proved Undeveloped Reserves.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Proved reserves that are expected to be recovered from new wells on
undrilled acreage or from existing wells where a relatively major expenditure is required for recompletion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Royalty.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;An interest in an oil and natural gas lease that gives the owner of the interest the right
to receive a portion of the production from the leased acreage (or of the proceeds of the sale thereof), but generally does not require the owner to pay any portion of the costs of drilling or
operating the wells on the leased acreage. Royalties may be either landowner's royalties, which are reserved by the owner of the leased acreage at the time the lease is granted, or overriding
royalties, which are usually reserved by an owner of the leasehold in connection with a transfer to a subsequent owner. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Secondary Recovery.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;An artificial method or process used to restore or increase production from a
reservoir after the primary production by the natural producing mechanism and reservoir pressure has experienced partial depletion. Gas injection and waterflooding are examples of this technique. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2-D Seismic.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The method by which a cross-section&nbsp;of the earth's subsurface is
created through the interpretation of reflecting seismic data collected along a single source profile. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;3-D Seismic.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The method by which a three dimensional image of the earth's subsurface is
created through the interpretation of reflection seismic data collected over a surface grid. 3-D seismic surveys allow for a more detailed understanding of the subsurface than do
conventional surveys and contribute significantly to field appraisal, exploitation and production.
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=26,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=633737,FOLIO='24',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DM1331A.;15',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:11' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1331_1_25"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tcf.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One trillion cubic feet of natural gas, measured at standard atmospheric conditions. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Tertiary Recovery.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;An enhanced recovery operation that normally occurs after waterflooding in which
chemicals or gasses are used as the injectant. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Waterflood.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;A secondary recovery operation in which water is injected into the producing formation in
order to maintain reservoir pressure and force oil toward and into the producing wells. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Working Interest.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;An interest in an oil and natural gas lease that gives the owner of the interest
the right to drill for and produce oil and natural gas on the leased acreage and requires the owner to pay a share of the costs of drilling and production operations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dm1331_item_2._properties"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dm1331_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 2. PROPERTIES    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Properties &#151; Principal Areas of Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our operations are concentrated in the following divisions: Northern, which includes properties in the Rocky Mountains, principally in North Dakota and Wyoming;
Southern, which includes properties principally in Oklahoma, Texas and Louisiana; and Gulf of Mexico, which includes our offshore properties. We operate approximately 70% of the net present value of
our reserves. We finance our exploitation, exploration and acquisition activities through cash flows from operations and through borrowings under our credit agreement and other financing activities.
Set forth below is summary information concerning average daily production during the fourth quarter of 2001 and estimated reserves and a pre-tax SEC net present value of estimated proved
reserves discounted at 10%, as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 in our divisions. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Northern Division  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Northern Division conducts operations in the Rocky Mountain region which includes the Williston, Powder River, Big Horn and Green River Basins. The Division
represented 25% of our net present value of estimated proved reserves as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 and contributed 28% of our fourth quarter 2001 production. We have interests in 731,788 developed
and 1,419,208 undeveloped gross acres in the region and in 1,862 gross (approximately 522 net) producing wells. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
strategy in the Northern Division is to develop lower-risk opportunities, exploit infill, horizontal and secondary/tertiary recovery opportunities on existing properties
and make tactical acquisitions to enhance current operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
March&nbsp;1, 2002 we completed the purchase of producing oil and gas properties located in the Williston Basin in North Dakota and Montana for approximately $38.7&nbsp;million.
We estimate the total proved reserves for these properties as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 to be approximately 53.1 Bcfe, of
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=27,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=96886,FOLIO='25',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DM1331A.;15',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:11' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1331_1_26"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
which approximately 90% is oil. The reserves are not included in the table above and these estimates have not been audited by our independent petroleum engineering firm. We will operate over 70% of
these properties, which have an average lifting cost of $0.51 per Mcfe. We estimate that net production from these properties will average approximately 13.9 Mmcfe/d in 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;North Dakota.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> Our two most active projects in North Dakota are in the South Fryburg Tyler area and the Wiley field. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>South Fryburg Tyler Area.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The South Fryburg Tyler area continues to be one of our most active
drilling programs. We continue development within the South Fryburg Tyler Unit, where we are the operator. We are also involved in exploration and development drilling in the Mission Canyon formation
on a contiguous acreage block southeast of the Unit. Within the South Fryburg Tyler Unit, we expanded the Tyler sand production with development drilling in 2001. On our acreage block adjoining the
Unit to the southeast, where we own over 76,000 gross acres, our drilling program targets zones within the Mission Canyon formation. We have participated in 26 horizontal wells on this acreage, 19 of
which were drilled in 2001. The 26 wells had initial production rates of approximately 190 bbl/d. In 2002, we expect to participate in an additional 4 to 8 wells on this block.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Wiley Field.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;We operate this waterflood with a 54% working interest. In 2000, we initiated a
horizontal drilling program with five wells and in 2001 drilled 17 wells, all of which were successful. In addition to the horizontal drilling, we increased water injection capacity to expand our
waterflood program. As a result of this activity, gross daily production has increased from approximately 600 bbl/d in April&nbsp;2000 to over 2,400 bbl/d at the end of 2001. Over the next
12&nbsp;months, we plan to drill 10 to 15 additional wells in this area while continuing to increase water injection capacity. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Wyoming.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> Our three primary areas of focus in Wyoming are the Big Horn Basin, the Powder River Basin and the Greater Green River area. The
Merger added in excess of 1.1&nbsp;million gross acres of exploratory acreage in the Big Horn, Wind River and Greater Green River gas basins of Wyoming. We plan to drill 15 to 20 exploration wells
in these areas over the next 12 to 24&nbsp;months. The wells will target multiple formations and successful projects hold the potential for multi-well development programs. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Big Horn Basin.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The Gooseberry field is our most significant property in the basin. We own a
100% working interest (nearly 90% net revenue interest) in this field, which consists of two waterflood units. Since acquiring the field in February&nbsp;1995, we have more than doubled the
production from approximately 535 bbl/d to over 1,100 bbl/d in December&nbsp;2001. This has been accomplished through the acquisition of proprietary 3-D seismic data, drilling of
delineation wells, installation of the two waterfloods and the addition of shallower producing zones. During the next 12&nbsp;months, we plan to drill from two to three additional wells and to
expand water injection capacity. In January&nbsp;2002 we placed a larger pipeline in service to accommodate the increasing production from the unit.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Powder River Basin.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;We currently own more than 27,000 net undeveloped acres in the Powder River
Basin, which we believe are prospective for coalbed methane drilling. In 2000 and 2001, we participated in the drilling of 178 wells, all of which were successful. We operate 84 of these wells. In
2002, we expect to participate in another 130 to 160 wells.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Greater Green River Area.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;One of the primary operating locations within the Greater Green River
area is the Moxa Arch Trend, where we drilled 16 wells in 2001, 14 of which were successful. This area represents a multi-year program where we have identified more than 100 potential
drilling locations on our acreage. Wells target the Frontier and Dakota formations at depths that range from approximately 10,000 to 12,500 feet. Production from Moxa Arch wells,
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=28,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=418723,FOLIO='26',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DM1331A.;15',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:11' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1331_1_27"> </A></FONT><P><FONT SIZE=2>particularly
from the Frontier formation, tends to be long-lived, with 25 to 30&nbsp;year reserve life potential. </FONT></P>

</DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Southern Division  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Southern Division conducts operations in the Permian Basin, Mid-Continent and onshore Gulf Coast regions. This division represented 43% of the net
present value of our estimated proved reserves as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 and contributed 41% of our fourth quarter 2001 production. We have interests in 578,252 developed and 165,939 undeveloped
gross acres and in 3,900 gross (approximately 1,603 net) producing wells. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Permian Basin.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> The Southern Division's principal Permian Basin properties are the Andrews Unit, Howard Glasscock Field and the Shafter
Lake San Andres Unit. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Andrews Unit.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The Andrews Unit, acquired as part of the Merger, produces from the Wolfcamp/Penn
formation at approximately 8,600 feet. We have a 98.6% working interest in this 3,230-acre Unit. Water injection began in late 1996 with the first response occurring in late 1998. During
2000 and 2001, we expanded the waterflood program by drilling additional wells, converting wells to injection, and performing workovers on existing wells. As a result, Unit production continues to
increase from an 855 bbl/d average in 2000 to 911 bbl/d average in 2001. We plan to drill two wells and convert two wells to injectors in 2002. We believe that production from this waterflood Unit can
be further enhanced with the use of CO<SUB>2</SUB> flooding or other tertiary recovery methods.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Howard Glasscock Field.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;We continue to exploit our 100% working interest in the Howard Glasscock
Field. Based on the results from adjacent successful waterfloods, we believe that additional potential exists through the installation of new and expansion of existing waterfloods on our leases. In
May&nbsp;2001, we initiated a drilling program for 27 injection and development wells to expand waterfloods on two of our leases. Water injection commenced in first quarter 2002. Additionally, we
have identified a number of opportunities for recompletion and well deepenings.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Shafter Lake San Andres Unit.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The Shafter Lake San Andres Unit, also acquired as part of the
Merger, is a 12,880-acre Unit that produces from the Grayburg and San Andres formations at a depth of approximately 4,500 feet. We have an 81.4% working interest in this secondary recovery
Unit. In 2002, we plan to drill eight wells on 10-acre spacing. Operators of nearby San Andres fields have successfully drilled to 10-acre spacing before CO<SUB>2</SUB>
injection. We believe the potential exists for CO<SUB>2</SUB> flooding as the field matures. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mid-Continent.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> The Southern Division's Mid-Continent operations are currently focused in Oklahoma and Kansas. Oil
production is concentrated in our operated waterfloods in Oklahoma, while natural gas production is primarily in third party operated wells in Oklahoma and in our operated wells in Kansas. The most
significant waterflood unit in Oklahoma is the Calumet Cottage Grove Unit, which we acquired as part of the Merger. We operate this secondary recovery Unit consisting of 11,400 acres in central
Oklahoma. Production is from the Pennsylvanian Cottage Grove formation at 8,100 feet. We have a 44.1% working interest in this Unit. In 2001, a total of seven wells were drilled, all of which were
successful and six of which were drilled prior to the Merger. We plan to drill four to six additional wells in 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Onshore Gulf Coast.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> The Southern Division's Gulf Coast operations are primarily focused in the Austin Chalk/Georgetown trend of
east-central Texas and in Northern Louisiana where we are active in two fields, the Elm Grove Field and the North Louisiana Field Complex. </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Austin Chalk/Georgetown Trend.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;The trend is a fractured carbonate formation that has been highly
conducive to the application of horizontal drilling technology. The Austin Chalk formation </FONT><P><FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=29,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=542031,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DM1331A.;15',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:11' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1331_1_28"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>is
encountered in this field at depths ranging between approximately 7,000 and 17,000 feet. The Georgetown formation, approximately 300 to 500 feet below the base of the Austin Chalk, has been a
secondary objective in the field. We control approximately 50,000 gross (13,000 net) undeveloped acres and 114,000 gross (43,000 net) developed acres in this area. In 2001, we participated in the
drilling of five Georgetown wells prior to the Merger and one Austin Chalk well after the Merger. All were successful. In 2002 we plan to re-enter six wells to drill Georgetown horizontal
sections. </FONT></P>

</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>Elm Grove Field.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;This field was drilled to extend the Cotton Valley production downdip from the
mature Caspiana field. In addition to the Cotton Valley, shallower secondary objectives include the Hosston and Rodessa intervals. Through the Merger we acquired an approximately 37%
non-operating working interest in the field. In 2001 a total of 42 wells were drilled, 17 of which were drilled after the Merger. All of the wells were successful. Gross production in the
field has increased from 34 Mmcfe/d in January&nbsp;2001 to 54 Mmcfe/d in December&nbsp;2001. In 2002, we plan to drill 25 to 30 wells.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>North Louisiana Field Complex.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;We acquired this interest in late 1998 and have identified over
100 development locations in its four fields&#151;Ada, Sibley, West Bryceland and Sailes. The 2,000 foot thick Hosston interval contains over 20 separate producing zones. In 2001, we drilled 34
wells, all of which were successful. We anticipate drilling between 35 and 45 wells in this region in each of the next two&nbsp;years. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gulf of Mexico Division  </I></B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The Gulf of Mexico Division represented 32% of the net present value of our estimated proved reserves as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 and contributed 31% of our
fourth quarter 2001 production. We have interests in 303,804 developed and 357,059 undeveloped gross acres in the Gulf of Mexico and in 158 gross (approximately 47 net) producing wells. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition to a production base with numerous exploitation opportunities within our developed acreage, the Gulf of Mexico provides us with moderate-risk exploration targets.
We drilled 16 exploratory wells in the Gulf of Mexico in 2001, 11 of which were successful. We have under license 3-D seismic data covering over 18,000 square miles (approximately 2,300
blocks) and 2-D seismic data covering 150,000 linear miles within the Gulf of Mexico. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;West Cameron Blocks 180/198.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> The West Cameron Blocks 180/198 complex consists of all or a portion of seven offshore blocks, including
30,000 gross developed and 5,000 gross undeveloped acres. This field was never owned by an independent producer prior to its purchase by Old Westport in October&nbsp;1997. The complex is located 30
miles offshore in 52 feet of water. It has produced approximately 1.7 Tcf of natural gas and 10 Mmbbl of oil from over 20 separate producing zones since its discovery. Since acquiring this field, we
have increased gross production from approximately 26 Mmcfe/d to 63 Mmcfe/d at year-end 2001. At the time of the acquisition, estimated proved reserves net to our interest were 77 Bcfe. As
of December&nbsp;31, 2001, we had 84 Bcfe of estimated proved reserves in the complex. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
the first quarter of 2001, we commenced production on three development wells drilled in 2000, and in the third quarter of 2001 we commenced production on three development wells
drilled in the first half of 2001. We also drilled a successful exploration well in the complex in 2001. The complex holds additional drilling opportunities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;West Cameron Blocks 613/614.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> In 1999, we discovered this field, located approximately 120 miles offshore in 290 feet of water. We drilled
a second exploration well on an adjoining block in the third quarter of 2000. We operate the field with a working interest of 50% and installed facilities and commenced production in
December&nbsp;2000. At year-end, the wells were producing at 22 Mmcfe/d (9 Mmcfe/d net). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=30,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=745306,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DM1331A.;15',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:11' -->
</FONT></P>

<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_do1331_1_29"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;West Cameron Block 370.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> We discovered this field, located approximately 60 miles offshore in 78 feet of water, in the fourth quarter of
2000. We operate the field with a 60% working interest. Following the discovery well we drilled three additional wells, installed a platform and commenced production in the third quarter of 2001. At
year-end, the wells were producing at 30 Mmcfe/d (15 Mmcfe/d net). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;East Cameron Block 369.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> We discovered this field in the first quarter of 2001 and commenced production from it in December&nbsp;2001. It
is located approximately 132 miles offshore in 350 feet of water. We operate the two-well field with a 60% working interest. At year-end, the wells were producing at 20 Mmcfe/d
(10 Mmcfe/d net). </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Vermilion Block 408.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> This field is located approximately 110 miles offshore in 400 feet of water and was discovered in 1999. We have a 25%
non-operated working interest in the field. A second well was drilled in this block in the third quarter of 2000. A third well was in progress at year end 2001. Facilities were installed
in late 2001 and production commenced in the first quarter of 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Mississippi Canyon Block 322.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> This field is located approximately 35 miles offshore in 750 feet of water and was discovered in the second
quarter of 2001. We own a non-operated 25% working interest in the field. A second well was also drilled. Both wells have been completed and production commenced in the first quarter of
2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Recent Discoveries.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> In 2002, we will continue to exploit the following discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>High Island Block 197.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;This field is located approximately 28 miles offshore in 50 feet of water
and was discovered in the third quarter of 2001. We have a 25% non-operated working interest in the field. A second well was in progress at year end 2001. In the first quarter of 2002, we
farmed into an adjoining block and an exploratory well is currently drilling. We expect a platform to be installed and production to be commenced in the second half of 2002.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>High Island Block 84.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;This field is located approximately 23 miles offshore in 50 feet of water
and was discovered in the third quarter of 2001. We operate the field with a 52% working interest. We plan to install a platform and commence production in the third quarter of 2002.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2><I>South Timbalier 316.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;We discovered this field located approximately 66 miles offshore in 300
feet of water, in the fourth quarter of 2001. We operate the field with a 40% working interest. Three wells have been drilled. We expect to install a platform and commence production in the second
half of 2003. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Exploration Activity.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> During 2002, we anticipate drilling eight to eleven exploration prospects.

<A NAME="page_do1331_1_30"> </A></FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="2%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="48">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
difference in net present value from December&nbsp;31, 2000 to December&nbsp;31, 2001 resulted almost entirely from (i)&nbsp;the addition of 502.7 Bcfe of proved reserves
acquired in connection with the Merger, (ii)&nbsp;the addition of 92 Bcfe as discoveries and extensions, (iii)&nbsp;the downward revision of 33 Bcfe due to revisions of previous estimates and
(iv)&nbsp;the decrease in commodity prices used to determine net present value (from $26.83 to $19.78 per bbl of oil and from $9.52 to $2.72 per Mmbtu of natural gas).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
difference in net present value from December&nbsp;31, 1999 to December&nbsp;31, 2000 resulted almost entirely from (i)&nbsp;the addition of 134 Bcfe of proved reserves
acquired in connection with the merger between Westport Oil and Gas and EPGC, (ii)&nbsp;the addition of 52 Bcfe as discoveries and extensions and (iii)&nbsp;the increase in commodity prices used
to determine net present value (from $25.60 to $26.83 per bbl of oil and from $2.30 to $9.52 per Mmbtu of natural gas).
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
standardized measure is the value of the future after-tax net revenues discounted at 10%. The difference between the net present value and the standardized measure is
the effect of income taxes discounted at 10%. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Estimated
quantities of oil and natural gas reserves and the present value thereof as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 are based upon a reserve report prepared by the Company's engineering
staff, 87% of the net present value of which was audited by the independent petroleum engineering firm of Ryder Scott Company, L.P. Estimated quantities of oil and natural gas reserves and the present
value thereof as of December&nbsp;31, 2000 are based upon reserve reports prepared by the independent petroleum engineering firms of Ryder Scott Company, L.P., Netherland Sewell and
Associates,&nbsp;Inc. and internal estimates. The Ryder Scott and Netherland Sewell reports covered approximately 85% of the net present value of the reserves and the net present value thereof.

<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=32,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=626122,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DO1331A.;10',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='18-MAR-2002;18:30' -->
<A NAME="page_do1331_1_31"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Proved
developed reserves are proved reserves that are expected to be recovered from existing wells with existing equipment and operating methods. Proved undeveloped reserves are proved
reserves that are expected to be recovered from new wells drilled to known reservoirs on undrilled acreage for which the existence and recoverability of such reserves can be estimated with reasonable
certainty, or from existing wells where a relatively major expenditure is required to establish production. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;There
are numerous uncertainties inherent in estimating quantities of proved reserves and in projecting future rates of production and timing of exploitation expenditures. The data in
the above tables represent estimates only. Oil and natural gas reserve engineering is inherently a subjective process of estimating underground accumulations of oil and natural gas that cannot be
measured exactly, and estimates of other engineers might differ materially from those shown above. The accuracy of any reserve estimate is a function of the quality of available data and engineering
and geological interpretation and judgment. Results of drilling, testing and production after the date of the estimate may justify revisions. Accordingly, reserve estimates may vary from the
quantities of oil and natural gas that are ultimately recovered. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Future
prices received for production and costs may vary, perhaps significantly, from the prices and costs assumed for purposes of these estimates. The present value shown should not be
construed as the current market value of the reserves. The 10% discount factor used to calculate present value, which is mandated by generally accepted accounting principles, is not necessarily the
most appropriate discount rate. The present value, no matter what discount rate is used, is materially affected by
assumptions as to timing of future production, which may prove to be inaccurate. For properties that we operate, expenses exclude our share of overhead charges. In addition, the calculation of
estimated future net revenues does not take into account the effect of various cash outlays, including, among other things, general and administrative costs and interest expense. </FONT></P>

of the periods indicated: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Acreage  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table sets forth information at December&nbsp;31, 2001 relating to acreage held by us. Developed acreage is assigned to producing wells.
Undeveloped acreage is acreage held under lease, permit, contract or option that is not in a spacing unit for a producing well, including leasehold interests identified for exploitation or exploratory
drilling. The term "gross acres" refers to the total number of acres in which we own a working interest. The term "net acres" refers to gross acres multiplied by our fractional working interest
therein. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="do1331_item_3._legal_proceedings"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1331_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 3. LEGAL PROCEEDINGS    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;From time to time, we may be a party to various legal proceedings. We are not currently party to any material pending legal proceedings. </FONT></P>

NAME="do1331_item_4._submission_of_m__do102400"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_do1331_2"> </A>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;No matters were submitted during the fourth quarter of the fiscal year covered by this Form&nbsp;10-K to a vote of our security holders, through the
solicitation of proxies or otherwise. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>

<!-- TOC_END -->
<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1331_part_ii"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1331_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>PART II    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1331_item_5._market_for_registrant___ite03067"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1331_2"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 5. MARKET FOR REGISTRANT'S COMMON EQUITY AND RELATED STOCKHOLDER MATTERS    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Price Range of Common Stock  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our common stock is listed and traded on the New York Stock Exchange, or NYSE, under the symbol "WRC." Prior to the Merger, Belco common stock was listed and
traded on the NYSE under the symbol "BOG." </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
August&nbsp;21, 2001, the effective date of the Merger, Old Westport was merged with and into Belco, with Belco surviving and changing its name to Westport Resources Corporation.
The Merger was accounted for as a purchase transaction for financial accounting purposes. Because former Old Westport stockholders now own a majority of the outstanding Westport common stock as a
result of the Merger, the Merger is accounted for as a reverse acquisition in which Old Westport is the purchaser of Belco. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
following table sets forth the high and low closing trading prices per share of Old Westport, Belco and Westport common stock on the NYSE, for the periods indicated: </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="87%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="48">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Stock
price information for periods prior to August&nbsp;21, 2001, the effective date of the Merger, are for shares of Belco common stock listed and traded on the NYSE under the
symbol "BOG." August&nbsp;20, 2001 was the last full trading day on which shares of Belco common stock were traded prior to the Merger.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Old
Westport commenced its initial public offering of common stock on October&nbsp;19, 2000 at a price of $15.00 per share. Fourth Quarter 2000 data is from October&nbsp;20, the
first day Old Westport's common stock was traded on the NYSE (under the symbol "WRC") through December&nbsp;31, 2000. August&nbsp;20, 2001 was the last full trading day on which shares of Old
Westport common stock were traded prior to the Merger.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
Merger became effective on August&nbsp;21, 2001. In accordance with the agreement governing the Merger, each outstanding share of Belco common stock was exchanged for 0.4125 of
a share of Westport common stock and each outstanding share of Old Westport stock was exchanged for one share of Westport common stock. </FONT></DD></DL>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Price Range of Preferred Stock  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our 6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible preferred stock is listed on the NYSE under the symbol "WRC_P." Prior to the Merger, Belco 6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible
preferred stock was listed and traded on the NYSE under the

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="48">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Stock
price information for periods prior to August&nbsp;21, 2001, the effective date of the Merger, are for shares of Belco 6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible preferred stock listed
and traded on the NYSE under the symbol "BOG_P." August&nbsp;20, 2001 was the last full trading day on which shares of Belco 6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible preferred stock were traded prior to the
Merger.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>The
Merger became effective on August&nbsp;21, 2001. In accordance with the agreement governing the Merger, each outstanding share of Belco 6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible
preferred stock was exchanged for one share of Westport 6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible preferred stock and became convertible into 0.465795 of a share of Westport common stock. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of March&nbsp;1, 2002, the closing price of our 6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible preferred stock was $19.00 per share, there were 2,930,000 shares of our
6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible preferred stock outstanding, convertible into 1,364,779 shares of our common stock at a rate of 0.465795 per share. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Dividend Policy  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We have never declared or paid any cash dividends on our common stock. We anticipate that we will retain all future earnings and other cash resources for
investment in our business. Accordingly, we do not intend to declare or pay cash dividends on our common stock in the foreseeable future. Payment of any future dividends on our common stock will be at
the discretion of our board of directors after taking into account many factors, including our financial condition, operating results, current and anticipated cash needs and plans for expansion. In
addition, our ability to declare and pay any dividends on our capital stock, including any outstanding preferred stock, may be limited or prohibited under the terms of our credit facility and the
indentures governing our senior subordinated debt obligations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
reported first quarter 2001 net income was insufficient to permit Belco to declare a dividend on its 6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible preferred stock under the terms of Belco's
indenture for Belco's 10<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2006, Belco's board of directors did not declare a preferred dividend for the preferred stock dividend due June&nbsp;15,
2001. Since the Merger, Westport has declared and paid all required dividends on its 6<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% convertible preferred stock, including dividends in arrears. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Recent Sales Of Unregistered Securities  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;None. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>

<A NAME="page_dq1331_1_36"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1331_item_6._selected_financial_data"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1331_3"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 6. SELECTED FINANCIAL DATA    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following table sets forth selected consolidated financial data for Westport as of the dates and for the periods indicated. The financial data for the
five&nbsp;years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 were derived from our Consolidated Financial Statements. Future results may differ substantially from historical results because of changes in oil and
natural gas prices, increases or decreases in production or other factors, many of which are beyond our control. The following data should be read in conjunction with "Management's Discussion and
Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations," which includes a discussion of factors materially affecting the comparability of the information presented, and our financial statements and
the notes thereto included elsewhere in this report. </FONT></P>
