<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="48">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Includes
compensation expenses of $3.4&nbsp;million recorded as a result of a one-time repurchase of employee stock options in March&nbsp;2000 in connection with the
merger between Westport Oil and Gas and EPGC. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dq1331_item_7._management_s_discussio__ite03668"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dq1331_4"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 7. MANAGEMENT'S DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATIONS    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Critical Accounting Policies And Estimates  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our discussion and analysis of Westport's financial condition and results of operation are based upon consolidated financial statements, which have been prepared
in accordance with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. The preparation of these financial statements requires us to
make estimates and judgments that affect the reported amounts of assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses. Our significant accounting policies are described in Note&nbsp;1 to our consolidated
financial statements. In response to SEC Release No.&nbsp;33-8040, "Cautionary Advice Regarding Disclosure About Critical Accounting Policies," we have identified certain of these
policies as being of particular importance to the portrayal of our financial position and results of operations and which require the application of significant judgment by our management. We analyze
our estimates, including those related to oil and gas revenues, oil and gas properties, fair value of derivative instruments, income taxes and contingencies and litigation, and base our estimates on
historical experience and various other assumptions that we believe to be reasonable under the circumstances. Actual results may differ from these estimates under different assumptions or conditions.
We believe
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=39,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=89225,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DQ1331A.;33',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1331_1_38"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
the following critical accounting policies affect our more significant judgments and estimates used in the preparation of our consolidated financial statements: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Revenue
Recognition. We follow the sales method of accounting for oil and natural gas revenues. Under this method, revenues are recognized based on actual
volumes of oil and natural gas sold to purchasers.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Successful
Efforts Accounting. We account for our oil and natural gas operations using the successful efforts method of accounting. Under this method, all
costs associated with property acquisition, successful exploratory wells and all development wells are capitalized. Items charged to expense generally include geological and geophysical costs, costs
of unsuccessful exploratory wells and oil and natural gas production costs. All of our oil and natural gas properties are located within the continental United States, the Gulf of Mexico and Canada.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Proved
Reserve Estimates. Estimates of our proved reserves included in this report are prepared in accordance with generally accepted accounting principals,
or GAAP, and SEC guidelines. The accuracy of a reserve estimate is a function of:
<BR><BR></FONT>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
quality and quantity of available data;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
interpretation of that data;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
accuracy of various mandated economic assumptions; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
judgment of the persons preparing the estimate. </FONT></DD></DL>
</DD></DL>
</UL>
<BR>
<UL>
<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Our
proved reserve information included in this report is based on estimates we prepared. Estimates prepared by others may be higher or lower than our estimates. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Because
these estimates depend on many assumptions, all of which may substantially differ from actual results, reserve estimates may be different from the quantities of oil and gas that are ultimately
recovered. In addition, results of drilling, testing and production after the date of an estimate may justify material revisions to the estimate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Our
stockholders should not assume that the present value of future net cash flows is the current market value of our estimated proved reserves. In accordance with SEC requirements, we based the
estimated discounted future net cash flows from proved reserves on prices and costs on the date of the estimate. Actual future prices and costs may be materially higher or lower than the prices and
costs as of the date of the estimate. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>Our
estimates of proved reserves materially impact depletion expense. If the estimates of proved reserves decline, the rate at which we record depletion expense increases, reducing net income. Such a
decline may result from lower market prices, which may make it uneconomic to drill for and produce higher cost fields. In addition, the decline in proved reserve estimates may impact the outcome of
our assessment of our oil and gas producing properties for impairment. </FONT></P>

</UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Impairment
of Proved Oil and Gas Properties. We review our long-lived proved properties to be held and used whenever management judges that
events or circumstances indicate that the recorded carrying value of the properties may not be recoverable. Management assesses whether or not an impairment provision is necessary based upon
management's outlook of future commodity prices and net cash flows that may be generated by the properties. Proved oil and gas properties are reviewed for impairment on a
field-by-field basis, which is the lowest level at which depletion of proved properties is calculated.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Impairment
of Unproved Oil and Gas Properties. Management periodically assesses individually significant unproved oil and gas properties for impairment, on a
project-by-project basis. Management's assessment of the results of exploration activities, commodity price outlooks, </FONT><P><FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=40,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=799590,FOLIO='38',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DQ1331A.;33',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1331_1_39"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>planned
future sales or expiration of all or a portion of such projects impact the amount and timing of impairment provisions. </FONT></P>

</DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Commodity
Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities. We periodically enter into commodity derivative contracts and fixed-price physical contracts to
manage our exposure to oil and natural gas price volatility. We primarily utilize price swaps, futures contracts or collars, which are generally placed with major financial institutions or with
counterparties of high credit quality that we believe are minimal
credit risks. The oil and natural gas reference prices of these commodity derivatives contracts are based upon crude oil and natural gas futures which have a high degree of historical correlation with
actual prices we receive. On January&nbsp;1, 2001, we adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;133, "Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities." Under SFAS No.&nbsp;133 all derivative
instruments are recorded on the balance sheet at fair value. Changes in the derivative's fair value are recognized currently in earnings unless specific hedge accounting criteria are met. For
qualifying cash flow hedges, the gain or loss on the derivative is deferred in accumulated other comprehensive income (loss) to the extent the hedge is effective. For qualifying fair value hedges, the
gain or loss on the derivative is offset by related results of the hedged item in the income statement. Gains and losses on hedging instruments included in accumulated other comprehensive income
(loss) are reclassified to oil and natural gas sales revenue in the period that the related production is delivered. Derivative contracts that do not qualify for hedge accounting treatment are
recorded as derivative assets and liabilities at market value in the consolidated balance sheet, and the associated unrealized gains and losses are recorded as current expense or income in the
consolidated statement of operations. While such derivative contracts do not qualify for hedge accounting, management believes these contracts can be utilized as an effective component of CPRM
activities. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Overview  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Westport is an independent energy company engaged in oil and natural gas exploitation, acquisition and exploration activities primarily in the United States. Our
reserves and production operations are concentrated in the following diversified divisions: Northern (Rocky Mountains); Southern (Permian Basin, Mid-Continent and Gulf Coast); and Gulf of
Mexico (offshore). We focus on maintaining a balanced portfolio of lower-risk, long-life onshore reserves and higher-margin offshore reserves to provide a diversified cash flow
foundation for our exploitation, acquisition and exploration activities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
results of operations are significantly impacted by the prices of oil and natural gas, which are volatile. In 2001, oil and natural gas prices decreased compared to prices in 2000.
Oil and natural gas prices declined from $9.52 per Mcf and $26.83 per bbl at the beginning of 2001 to $2.72 per Mcf and $19.78 per bbl at December&nbsp;31, 2001. The prices we receive for our oil
vary from NYMEX prices based on the location and quality of the crude oil. The prices we receive for our natural gas are based on Henry Hub prices reduced by transportation and processing fees. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Oil
and natural gas production costs are composed of lease operating expense and production taxes. Lease operating expense consists of pumpers' salaries, utilities, maintenance and other
costs necessary to operate our producing properties. In general, lease operating expense per unit of production is lower on our offshore properties and does not fluctuate proportionately with our
production. Production taxes are assessed by applicable taxing authorities as a percentage of revenues. However, properties located in Federal waters offshore are generally not subject to production
taxes. Transportation costs are comprised of costs paid to a carrier to deliver oil or natural gas to a specified delivery point. In some cases we receive a payment from the purchases of our oil and
natural gas which is net of gas transportation costs and in other instances we pay the costs of transportation.
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=41,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=36274,FOLIO='39',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DQ1331A.;33',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1331_1_40"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploration
expense consists of geological and geophysical costs, delay rentals and the cost of unsuccessful exploratory wells. Delay rentals are typically fixed in nature in the short
term. However, other exploration costs are generally discretionary and exploration activity levels are determined by a number of factors, including oil and natural gas prices, availability of funds,
quantity and character of investment projects, availability of service providers and competition. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depletion
of capitalized costs of producing oil and natural gas properties is computed using the units-of-production method based upon proved reserves. For
purposes of computing depletion, proved reserves are redetermined twice each year. Because the economic life of each producing well depends upon the assumed price for production, fluctuations in oil
and natural gas prices impact the level of proved reserves. Higher prices generally have the effect of increasing reserves, which reduces depletion, while lower prices generally have the effect of
decreasing reserves, which increases depletion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
assess our proved properties on a field-by-field basis for impairment, in accordance with the provisions of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards
No.&nbsp;121, "Accounting for the Impairment of Long Lived Assets and for Long Lived Assets to be Disposed of," whenever events or circumstances indicate that the capitalized costs of oil and
natural gas properties may not be recoverable. When making such assessments, we compare the expected undiscounted future net revenues on a field-by-field basis with the related
net capitalized costs at the end of each period. When the net capitalized costs exceed the undiscounted future net revenues, the cost of the property is written down to "fair value," which is
determined using discounted future net revenues based on escalated prices. Impairments for the&nbsp;years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, 2000 and 1999, were calculated based on the following
prices: oil prices per barrel of $20.84, $24.70 and $20.84, respectively; and natural gas prices per Mcf of $2.75, $4.48 and $2.36, respectively. Oil and natural gas prices were both escalated
annually at 2.5% in 2000 and 1999. Natural gas prices for 2001 were increased from $2.75 per Mcf in 2002 to $3.05 per Mcf in 2003 and then escalated at 2.5% thereafter. Estimates of declining
production were based on internal estimates of which 87% of the net present value was audited by independent reserve engineers and estimated operating costs and severance taxes were based on past
experience. Operating and future development costs were escalated annually at 2.5% in 2001, 2000 and 1999. Reserve categories used in the impairment analysis for all periods considered are categories
of proven reserves and probable and possible reserves, which were risk adjusted based on our drilling plans and history of successfully developing those types of reserves. We periodically assess our
unproved properties to determine if any such properties have been impaired. Such assessment is based on, among other things, the fair value of properties located in the same area as the unproved
property and our intent to pursue additional exploration opportunities on such property. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock
compensation expense consists of noncash charges resulting from the application of the provisions of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;44 to certain stock options granted to
employees, issuance of restricted stock to certain employees and a one time expense related to the repurchase of employee stock options in March&nbsp;2000. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;General
and administrative expenses consist primarily of salaries and related benefits, office rent, legal fees, consultants, systems costs and other administrative costs incurred in our
Denver, Dallas and
Houston offices. While we expect such costs to increase with our growth, we expect such increases to be proportionately smaller than our production growth. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Mergers  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On August&nbsp;21, 2001, the stockholders of Belco approved the Agreement and Plan of Merger, dated as of June&nbsp;8, 2001, between Belco and Westport.
Pursuant to the merger agreement, Old Westport was merged with and into Belco, with Belco surviving and changing its name to Westport Resources Corporation. The Merger was accounted for as a purchase
transaction for financial accounting purposes. Because former Old Westport stockholders now own a majority of the
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=42,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=853068,FOLIO='40',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DQ1331A.;33',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1331_1_41"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
outstanding Westport common stock as a result of the Merger, the Merger is accounted for as a reverse acquisition in which Old Westport is the purchaser of Belco. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Old
Westport was formed by the merger on April&nbsp;7, 2000 of Westport Oil and Gas with EPGC. As a result of the merger, Westport Oil and Gas became a wholly-owned subsidiary of EPGC,
which subsequently changed its name to Westport Resources Corporation, and the stockholders of Westport Oil and Gas became the majority stockholders of EPGC. The senior management team of Westport Oil
and Gas became the management team for the combined company, complemented by certain key managers from EPGC. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Results of Operations  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As indicated above, the merger between Belco and Old Westport was accounted for using purchase accounting with Old Westport as the surviving accounting entity. We
began consolidating the results of Belco with the results of Old Westport as of the August&nbsp;21, 2001 closing date. The merger between EPGC and Westport Oil and Gas was accounted for using
purchase accounting with Westport Oil and Gas as the surviving accounting entity. Old Westport began consolidating the results of EPGC with the results of Westport Oil and Gas as of the
April&nbsp;7, 2000 closing date. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
discussion below includes a comparison of our consolidated results of operations for the&nbsp;years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, 2000 and 1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revenues.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Oil and natural gas revenues for 2001 increased by $72.6&nbsp;million, or 30%, from
$244.7&nbsp;million in 2000 to $317.3&nbsp;million in 2001. Production from the acquired Belco properties accounted for $49.6&nbsp;million of the increase. Revenue increased $37.1&nbsp;million
from recent discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico. The increases were partially offset by decreases of 22% and 15% in realized oil and natural gas prices, respectively. Production volumes increased 32.3
Bcfe from 55.8 Bcfe in 2000
to 88.1 Bcfe in 2001 (acquired Belco and EPGC properties accounted for 19.2 Bcfe and 0.7 Bcfe of the increase, respectively). Production volumes also increased 10.7 Bcfe from recent discoveries in the
Gulf of Mexico, 0.6 Bcfe from coalbed methane development in the Powder River Basin area, 0.8 Bcfe from the horizontal drilling program in the Wiley field, and 0.6 Bcfe from the acquired interest in
the Ward Estes field in August&nbsp;2000. Increases were partially offset by declines in existing properties. Hedging transactions had the effect of increasing oil and natural gas revenues by
$2.1&nbsp;million in 2001, or $0.2 per Mcfe, and reducing oil and natural gas revenues by $24.6&nbsp;million in 2000, or $0.44 per Mcfe. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Oil
and natural gas revenues for 2000 increased by $161.3&nbsp;million, or 193%, from $83.4&nbsp;million in 1999 to $244.7&nbsp;million in 2000. Production from the acquired EPGC
properties accounted for $95.3&nbsp;million of the increase and the remaining increase resulted from increases of 70% and 92% in realized oil and natural gas prices, respectively. The increase of
22,709 Mmcfe in production volumes from 33,113 Mmcfe in 1999 to 55,822 Mmcfe in 2000 was primarily due to 21,260 Mmcfe from the acquired EPGC properties. Hedging transactions had the effect of
reducing oil and natural gas revenues by $24.6&nbsp;million and $7.9&nbsp;million, or $0.44 and $0.24 per Mcfe, for the&nbsp;years ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 and 1999, respectively. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Commodity Price Risk Management Activities, or CPRM, Activities.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;For 2001, we recorded a net gain of
$14.3&nbsp;million in the non-hedge change in fair value of derivatives compared to a net loss of $0.7&nbsp;million for 2000. A net gain of $15.3&nbsp;million was recorded in 2001
for non-hedge settlements of derivatives. The net gains in 2001 and the net loss in 2000 relate to settlements of derivatives and changes in fair value on derivatives that under SFAS
No.&nbsp;133 do not qualify for hedge accounting. Westport Oil and Gas did not have any derivatives that qualified for hedge accounting for 1999.
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=43,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=595286,FOLIO='41',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DQ1331A.;33',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_dq1331_1_42"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gain (Loss) on Sale of Operating Assets.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;For 2001, we recorded a loss on sale of operating assets of
$0.1&nbsp;million compared to gains of $3.1&nbsp;million in 2000 and $3.6&nbsp;million in 1999 primarily from the sale of offshore properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lease Operating Expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Lease operating expense for 2001 increased by $20.9&nbsp;million, or 61%,
from $34.4&nbsp;million in 2000 to $55.3&nbsp;million in 2001. Lease operating expenses from the acquired EPGC properties and Belco properties accounted for $1.3&nbsp;million and
$11.4&nbsp;million, respectively, of the increase. Recent discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico, an increased level of workovers in several of our properties and a general increase in the cost of oil
field services and materials accounted for the remainder. On a per Mcfe basis, lease operating expense remained relatively constant at $0.62 in 2000 and $0.63 in 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Lease
operating expense for 2000 increased by $11.5&nbsp;million, or 50%, from $22.9&nbsp;million in 1999 to $34.4&nbsp;million in 2000. Lease operating expenses from the acquired
EPGC properties accounted for $6.5&nbsp;million of the increase. On a per Mcfe basis, lease operating expense decreased from $0.69 to
$0.62, primarily due to the lower lease operating expense associated with the acquired EPGC properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Production Taxes.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Production taxes for 2001 increased by $2.8&nbsp;million, or 26%, from
$10.6&nbsp;million in 2000 to $13.4&nbsp;million, in 2001. Acquired Belco properties accounted for $3.7&nbsp;million of the increase in production taxes. The increase from the acquired Belco
properties is partially offset by a decrease in revenue from onshore properties as a result of a decrease in realized oil and natural gas prices. As a percent of oil and natural gas revenues
(excluding the effects of hedges), production taxes remained relatively constant at 4.3% in 2000 and 4.2% in 2001. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Production
taxes for 2000 increased by $4.9&nbsp;million, or 85%, from $5.7&nbsp;million in 1999 to $10.6&nbsp;million in 2000. The increase in production taxes is primarily
attributable to an increase in the average realized price of oil and natural gas. As a percent of oil and natural gas revenues (excluding the effects of hedges), production taxes decreased from 6.9%
to 4.3%. The decrease in production taxes as a percent of revenue is primarily the result of the EPGC merger, which increased the number of offshore properties that are not subject to production
taxes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Transportation Costs.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Transportation costs for 2001 increased by $2.2&nbsp;million, or 70%, from
$3.0&nbsp;million in 2000 to $5.2&nbsp;million in 2001. The increase was primarily due to additional offshore and coalbed methane wells that started producing in the latter part of 2000 and early
2001, which incur higher costs to transport the natural gas. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Transportation
costs for 2000 increased by $1.3&nbsp;million, or 76%, from $1.7&nbsp;million in 1999 to $3.0&nbsp;million in 2000. Transportation costs from the acquired EPGC
properties accounted for $0.4&nbsp;million of the increase. The remaining increase was due to additional offshore natural gas wells and coalbed methane wells that started producing in 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploration Costs.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploration costs for 2001 increased by $18.5&nbsp;million, or 145%, from
$12.8&nbsp;million in 2000 to $31.3&nbsp;million in 2001. Dry hole costs increased $13.1&nbsp;million as a result of six unsuccessful exploratory wells drilled in the Gulf of Mexico during 2001.
For 2000 there were five unsuccessful exploratory offshore wells and three unsuccessful exploratory onshore wells. Purchases of Gulf of Mexico seismic data increased $4.8&nbsp;million during 2001
compared to 2000. Exploration costs increased $0.6&nbsp;million from the acquired Belco properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=44,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=292207,FOLIO='42',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DQ1331A.;33',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
</FONT></P>

<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_ds1331_1_43"> </A> </FONT></P>

<!-- TOC_END -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Exploration costs for 2000 increased by $5.5&nbsp;million, or 75%, from $7.3&nbsp;million in 1999 to $12.8&nbsp;million in 2000. Exploration costs consisted of $6.0&nbsp;million
of dry hole costs, $5.6&nbsp;million of geological and geophysical costs and $1.2&nbsp;million of delay rentals. The increase was primarily due to $4.0&nbsp;million in additional dry hole costs
as a result of five unsuccessful offshore exploratory wells and three unsuccessful onshore exploratory wells drilled during 2000. Geological and geophysical costs increased $1.0&nbsp;million due to
increased offshore activity in 2000. Delay rentals accounted for $0.5&nbsp;million of the increase as a result of acquiring offshore leases in the EPGC merger. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depletion, Depreciation and Amortization, or DD&amp;A, Expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;DD&amp;A expense increased
$59.2&nbsp;million in 2001, from $64.9&nbsp;million in 2000 to $124.1&nbsp;million in 2001. Depletion related to the acquired EPGC properties and Belco properties caused DD&amp;A expense to increase
$6.4&nbsp;million and $31.7&nbsp;million, respectively. Recent discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico caused DD&amp;A expense to increase $14.8&nbsp;million. An increase of $2.1&nbsp;million was
primarily due to additions in oil and natural gas properties in northern Louisiana in 2001. The remaining increase was primarily due to the additions of oil and natural gas properties during 2001.
These increases were the primary factors that caused DD&amp;A expense to increase on a per Mcfe basis from $1.16 in 2000 to $1.41 in 2001. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;DD&amp;A
expense increased $39.7&nbsp;million during 2000 from $25.2&nbsp;million in 2000 to $64.9&nbsp;million in 2001. Depletion related to the acquired EPGC properties caused DD&amp;A
expense to increase $36.8&nbsp;million. The remaining increase was due to the additions in oil and natural gas properties during 2000. The average DD&amp;A rate increased from $0.76 per Mcfe during 1999
to $1.16 per Mcfe during 2000, a 53% increase in the DD&amp;A rates primarily due to the acquired offshore EPGC properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Impairment of Proved Properties.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;During 2001, 2000 and 1999, we recognized proved property
impairments of $9.4&nbsp;million, $2.9&nbsp;million and $3.1&nbsp;million, respectively. Impairments recorded in 2001 were as follows: $4.9&nbsp;million based on the results of unsuccessful
development drilling in the Rocky Mountains, $1.5&nbsp;million resulting from depressed oil and natural gas prices in the Rocky Mountains and Mid-Continent, $0.9&nbsp;million based on
the results of unsuccessful development drilling in the Gulf of Mexico and $2.1&nbsp;million resulting from depressed natural gas prices in the Gulf of Mexico. Impairments recorded in 2000 were
mainly the result of a decline in oil and natural gas reserve value due to reserve volume reductions in underperforming fields in Wyoming, offshore and Louisiana. The impairment recorded in 1999 was
the result of a decrease in risk adjusted probable reserves for the Ward Estes lease located in West Texas, which were subsequently assigned to the operator of the lease in exchange for existing
producing property equipment and infrastructure owned by the operator. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Impairment of Unproved Properties.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2001, we recognized unproved property impairments of
$7.0&nbsp;million on offshore leases, as a result of an assessment of the exploration opportunities existing on such properties. In 2000, we recognized unproved property impairments of
$5.1&nbsp;million, as a result of an assessment of the exploration opportunities existing on such properties. The $5.1&nbsp;million consisted of $2.5&nbsp;million for leases held in North
Dakota, $1.5&nbsp;million for leases held offshore and $1.1&nbsp;million for various leases held in Kansas, Wyoming and Louisiana. In 1999, we recognized unproved property impairments of
$2.3&nbsp;million of which $1.3&nbsp;million was associated with a prospect off the coast of Argentina and the remaining $1.0&nbsp;million was for various leases held in North Dakota and
Wyoming. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Stock Compensation Expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;In 2001, we recorded $0.7&nbsp;million in stock compensation expense
consisting of $0.4&nbsp;million as a result of applying the provisions of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;44 and $0.3&nbsp;million in expense related to the issuance of restricted stock. In 2000,
we recognized $5.5&nbsp;million of stock compensation expense due to a $3.4&nbsp;million one-time stock compensation
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=45,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=1021985,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DS1331A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1331_1_44"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
expense related to the repurchase of employee stock options and $2.1&nbsp;million related to provisions of FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;44. There was no stock compensation expense recorded in
1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;General and Administrative, or G&amp;A, Expense.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;G&amp;A expense increased $10.2&nbsp;million in 2001, or
134%, from $7.5&nbsp;million in 2000 to $17.7&nbsp;million in 2001. In connection with the EPGC merger additional employees were hired in the Houston office which accounted for a
$3.0&nbsp;million increase in G&amp;A expense. The Merger accounted for $4.2&nbsp;million of the increase. A majority of the remaining increase was due to payroll costs resulting from an increase in
staff in 2001 reflecting expanded size and scope of our operations as a result of our reporting obligations under the Exchange Act. On an Mcfe basis, G&amp;A expense in 2001 was $0.20 compared to $0.14 in
2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;G&amp;A
expense increased $2.2&nbsp;million, or 42%, during 2000, from $5.3&nbsp;million in 1999 to $7.5&nbsp;million in 2000. In connection with the EPGC merger additional employees
were hired in the Houston office, which accounted for a $3.4&nbsp;million increase in G&amp;A expense. Offsetting the increase in G&amp;A expense was a $0.6&nbsp;million increase in overhead recoveries
from additional drilling in 2000 and $0.5&nbsp;million additional costs incurred in 1999 related to closing an office acquired in an acquisition. On an Mcfe basis, G&amp;A expense decreased 13% from
$0.16 during 1999 to $0.14 during 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other Income (Expense).</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Other expense for 2001 was ($6.4&nbsp;million) compared to
($8.3&nbsp;million) for 2000. Interest expense increased $3.5&nbsp;million in 2001, as a result of the increase in the debt balance relating to the Merger. Other income increased
$5.4&nbsp;million as compared to 2000 primarily due to an increase in interest income of $0.4&nbsp;million and changes in fair values of $5.0&nbsp;million on interest rate swap contracts that
were not designated as hedges for accounting purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
income (expense) for 2000 was ($8.3&nbsp;million) compared to ($8.7&nbsp;million) for 1999. The variance was primarily due to interest expense which increased
$0.5&nbsp;million from $9.2&nbsp;million in 1999 to $9.7&nbsp;million in 2000 as a result of $50&nbsp;million in additional borrowings relating to the EPGC merger.
The increase in interest expense was offset by an increase in interest income and other of $0.9&nbsp;million primarily due to an increase in average cash balance during 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Taxes.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;We recorded income tax expense of $28.6&nbsp;million ($26.6&nbsp;million deferred
and $2.0&nbsp;million current) for 2001 and $23.7&nbsp;million ($23.0&nbsp;million deferred and $0.7&nbsp;million current) for 2000. The difference between the income tax expense for those
periods and the amounts that would be calculated by applying statutory income tax rates to income before income taxes is due primarily to the utilization of credits generated from applying enhanced
recovery methods in both periods. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
recorded income tax expense of $23.7&nbsp;million for 2000 and no income tax expense or benefit for 1999 resulting from a loss incurred in 1999. The difference between the income
tax expense (benefit) for those periods and the amounts that would be calculated by applying statutory income tax rates to income before income taxes is due primarily to the credits from applying
enhanced recovery methods in 2000 and a deferred tax valuation allowance recorded in 1999. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B><I>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net Income.</I></B></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;Net income for 2001 was $49.8&nbsp;million compared to net income of
$43.5&nbsp;million for 2000. The variance was primarily attributable to increases in revenues of $126.4&nbsp;million and decrease in other expense of $2.0&nbsp;million offset by increases of
$117.2&nbsp;million in operating expenses and $4.9&nbsp;million in income tax expense. On a per share basis net income declined to $1.11 per basic share, $1.09 fully diluted from $1.54 per basic
share, $1.52 fully diluted due to an increase of 13.7&nbsp;million shares outstanding. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
income for 2000 was $43.5&nbsp;million compared to a net loss of $3.1&nbsp;million for 1999. The variance was primarily attributable to an increase in revenues of
$143.3&nbsp;million, partially offset by increases of $73.3&nbsp;million in operating expenses and $23.7&nbsp;million in income tax expense. On a per

<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=46,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=646696,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DS1331A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1331_1_45"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
share basis net loss was $0.21 per basic and diluted share in 1999, compared to net income of $1.54 per basic share and $1.52 per diluted share in 2000. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our principal uses of capital have been for the exploitation, acquisition and exploration of oil and natural gas properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
flow from operating activities was $195.3&nbsp;million for 2001 compared to $143.4&nbsp;million for 2000. Operating cash flow in 2001 increased compared to 2000 due to a 58%
increase in production as a result of the mergers with EPGC and Belco, recent discoveries in the Gulf of Mexico, and additional production from coalbed methane development from the Wiley and Ward
Estes fields. Cash flow from
operating activities increased $122.1&nbsp;million from $21.3&nbsp;million for 1999 to $143.4&nbsp;million for 2000 due to a 77% increase in commodity prices and as a result of the merger with
EPGC. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
flow used in investing activities was $188.7&nbsp;million for 2001 compared to $140.2&nbsp;million for 2000. Investing activities for 2001 include $187.9&nbsp;million used for
exploitation and exploration activities and $6.3&nbsp;million used for acquisitions, offset by proceeds from sales of properties of $5.5&nbsp;million. Investing activities for 2000 included
$102.2&nbsp;million for exploitation and exploration activities and $43.9&nbsp;million for acquisitions ($42.4&nbsp;million related to the merger with EPGC), offset by proceeds from sales of
properties of $6.3&nbsp;million. Cash flow used in investing activities was $140.2&nbsp;million for 2000 compared to cash flow generated in 1999 of $18.0&nbsp;million. Cash generated in 1999 was
due in part to $32.0&nbsp;million of proceeds from sales of oil and natural gas properties, offset by $14.0&nbsp;million in additions to oil and natural gas properties. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
cash generated in financing activities was $0.8&nbsp;million for 2001 compared to $2.6&nbsp;million cash used in 2000. Financing activities for 2001 consisted of
$577.6&nbsp;million in repayment of long-term debt, new financing fees of $10.2&nbsp;million, stock repurchase of $0.4&nbsp;million and preferred stock dividend of
$1.6&nbsp;million offset by $590.0&nbsp;million in borrowings and $0.6&nbsp;million from the issuance of common stock. Financing activities for 2000 reflected borrowings of $50.0&nbsp;million
utilized to consummate the merger with EPGC and $104.1&nbsp;million from the issuance of common stock offset by repayments of long-term debt of $156.6&nbsp;million. Net cash used in
financing activities was $2.6&nbsp;million for 2000 compared to net cash used in 1999 of $29.9&nbsp;million. Cash was used in 1999 for repayments of long-term debt of
$46.3&nbsp;million offset by proceeds of $16.4&nbsp;million from the issuance of common stock. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Financing Activity  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The following summarizes our contractual obligations at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and the effect such obligations are expected to have on our liquidity and cash
flow in future periods. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Revolving Credit Facility  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We entered into a new credit facility, which we refer to as the Revolving Credit Facility, with a syndicate of banks upon closing of the Merger. The Revolving
Credit Facility, as amended on
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=47,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=433619,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DS1331A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1331_1_46"> </A></FONT> <FONT SIZE=2>
November&nbsp;5, 2001, provides for a maximum committed amount of $500&nbsp;million and a borrowing base of approximately $400&nbsp;million as of December&nbsp;31, 2001. The facility matures
on July&nbsp;1, 2005. Advances under the Revolving Credit Facility are in the form of either a base rate loan or a Eurodollar loan. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
interest on a base rate loan is a fluctuating rate based upon the highest of: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
rate of interest announced by JP Morgan Chase Bank, formerly known as The Chase Manhattan Bank, as its prime rate;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
secondary market rate for three month certificates of deposits plus 1%; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>the
Federal funds effective rate plus 0.5%; </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>in
each case plus a margin of 0% to 0.125% based upon the ratio of total debt to EBITDAX. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
interest on a Eurodollar loan is a fluctuating rate based upon the rate at which Eurodollar deposits in the London interbank market are quoted plus a margin of 1.25% to 1.50% based
upon the ratio of total debt to EBITDAX. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2001, we had borrowings of $35.0&nbsp;million (with an average interest rate of 3.25%) and letters of credit issued of approximately $3.8&nbsp;million
outstanding under the Revolving Credit Facility, and available unused borrowing capacity of approximately $361.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Redemption of 10<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2006  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;20, 2001, we redeemed all of our outstanding 10<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2006 at a price of $1,052.50 per note plus
accrued interest. The notes were originally issued by Coda Energy and assumed in connection with the Merger, and they were redeemed pursuant to the optional redemption provision of the related
indenture at 105.25% of the principal amount of each note plus accrued interest, for a total amount of approximately $120.1&nbsp;million, consisting of $114.7&nbsp;million in principal and
$5.4&nbsp;million in accrued interest. The redemption was funded by borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility and available cash. No gain or loss was recognized in connection with the
redemption as the fair value of the 10<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>2</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes recorded in connection with the Merger equaled the redemption cost. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> 8<SUP>7</SUP>/<SMALL>8</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2007  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In connection with the Merger, we assumed $147&nbsp;million face amount, $149&nbsp;million fair value, of Belco's 8<SUP>7</SUP>/<SMALL>8</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated
Notes due 2007. On November&nbsp;1, 2001, approximately $24.3&nbsp;million face amount of these notes was tendered to us pursuant to the change of control provisions of the
related indenture. The tender price was equal to 101% of the principal amount of each note plus accrued and unpaid interest as of October&nbsp;29, 2001. Including the premium and accrued interest,
the total amount paid was $24.8&nbsp;million. We used borrowings under our Revolving Credit Facility to fund the repayment. No gain or loss was recorded in connection with the redemption as the fair
value of the 8<SUP>7</SUP>/<SMALL>8</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes recorded in connection with the Merger equaled the redemption cost. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> 8<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>4</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2011  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On November&nbsp;5, 2001, we completed the private placement of $275&nbsp;million of 8<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>4</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2011 pursuant to SEC
rule&nbsp;144A. Proceeds of approximately $268&nbsp;million, net of underwriting discounts and offering costs, were used to reduce outstanding indebtedness under the Revolving Credit Facility. On
March&nbsp;14, 2002 we completed the exchange of these notes for new notes with substantially identical terms, except that the new notes are generally freely tradeable.
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=48,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=973439,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DS1331A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1331_1_47"> </A></FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Stock Repurchase  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On September&nbsp;21, 2001, the board of directors authorized management to repurchase up to $30&nbsp;million of our common stock. Under this authorization,
we have repurchased 30,000 shares at an average price of $13.61 per share including broker commissions. </FONT></P>

<UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><I> Capital Expenditures  </I></FONT></P>

</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We anticipate that our capital expenditures for 2002 will be approximately $170&nbsp;million. Our capital expenditures for 2001 were $187.9&nbsp;million, not
including acquisitions. We anticipate that our primary cash requirements for 2002 will include funding acquisitions, funding development projects and general working capital needs. We will continue to
seek opportunities for acquisitions of proved reserves with substantial exploitation and exploration potential. The size and timing of capital requirements for acquisitions is inherently unpredictable
and we therefore do not budget for them. We expect to fund our capital expenditure activities, which include acquisition, development of and exploration on our oil and natural gas properties through
cash flow from operations and available capacity under our Revolving Credit Facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
believe that borrowings under the Revolving Credit Facility, projected operating cash flows and cash on hand will be sufficient to meet the requirements of our business. However,
future cash flows are subject to a number of variables including the level of production and oil and natural gas prices. We cannot assure you that operations and other capital resources will provide
cash in sufficient amounts to maintain planned levels of capital expenditures or that increased capital expenditures will not be undertaken. Actual levels of capital expenditures may vary
significantly due to a variety of factors, including but not limited to: </FONT></P>

<UL>
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>drilling
results;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>product
prices;
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>industry
conditions and outlook; and
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>&#149;</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>future
acquisition of properties. </FONT></DD></DL>
</UL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="ds1331_item_7a._quantitative_and_qual__ite02669"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_ds1331_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>ITEM 7A. QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE DISCLOSURES ABOUT MARKET RISK    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We periodically enter into commodity price risk management, or CPRM, transactions to manage our exposure to oil and gas price volatility. CPRM transactions may
take the form of futures contracts, swaps or options. All CPRM data is presented in accordance with requirements of SFAS No.&nbsp;133, which we adopted on January&nbsp;1, 2001. Accordingly,
unrealized gains and losses related to the change in fair market value of derivative contracts that qualify and are designated as cash flow hedges are recorded as other comprehensive income or loss
and such amounts are reclassified to oil and natural gas sales revenues as the associated production occurs. Derivative contracts that do not qualify for hedge accounting treatment are recorded as
derivative assets and liabilities at market value in the consolidated balance sheet, and the associated unrealized gains and losses are recorded as current expense or income in the consolidated
statement of operations. While such derivative contracts do not qualify for hedge accounting, management believes these contracts can be utilized as an effective component of CPRM activities. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
2001, we recorded increases in operating revenues from non-hedge CPRM settlements in the amount of $15.3&nbsp;million, which includes $3.6&nbsp;million of cash
settlements and non-hedge change in fair value of derivatives of $14.3&nbsp;million. For 2000, we recorded a decrease in operating revenues from non-hedge change in fair
value of derivatives of $0.7&nbsp;million.
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=49,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=572751,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]DS1331A.;20',USER='MBRADT',CD='18-MAR-2002;21:12' -->
<A NAME="page_ds1331_1_48"> </A></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
2001, we recorded hedging settlement gains in the amount of $2.1&nbsp;million, which include cash losses of $4.5&nbsp;million and for 2000 and 1999 we recorded hedging settlement
losses of $24.6&nbsp;million and $7.9&nbsp;million, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Prior
to the Merger, Belco entered into a substantial portion of its natural gas and crude oil commodity swap agreements and option agreements with Enron North America Corp., or ENA,
formerly known as Enron Capital&nbsp;&amp; Trade Resources Corp., a wholly owned subsidiary of Enron Corp. Mr.&nbsp;Robert A. Belfer, one of our directors, is a member of the Board of Directors of
Enron Corp. and was the CEO of Belco at the time these transactions were entered into. These agreements were entered into in the ordinary course of business of Belco and on terms that we believe were
no less favorable to Belco than the terms of similar arrangements with third parties. Old Westport also entered into commodity price risk management agreements with ENA prior to the Merger. Pursuant
to the terms of these agreements Belco paid ENA a net amount of approximately $32&nbsp;million in fiscal year 2000 and approximately $45&nbsp;million in 2001. Old Westport and Westport received a
net amount of $1.6&nbsp;million in 2001 from ENA. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
November&nbsp;29, 2001, we terminated our commodity derivative contracts with Enron North America Corp., or ENA, formerly known as Enron Capital&nbsp;&amp; Trade Resources Corp., a
wholly-owned subsidiary of Enron Corp. We exercised our rights pursuant to the early termination provisions of such contracts as a result of ENA's bankruptcy filing and related events. We believe that
we had the legal right to terminate these agreements, but ENA may challenge our termination in bankruptcy court. Applying the mark-to-market and setoff methodology of our
contracts with ENA, we have calculated that we owed ENA a net $204,000 for all hedging transactions outstanding under our ENA contracts. Although we believe this methodology was correct, it is
possible that ENA will challenge our calculations and claim larger amounts are owed. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of March&nbsp;12, 2002, we have approximately 3.5&nbsp;million barrels of oil and 17.5 Bcf of natural gas subject to CPRM contracts for 2002. The 2002 contracts have weighted
average floor prices of $22.00 per barrel and $2.90 per Mmbtu, with weighted average ceiling prices of $24.68 per barrel and $3.14 per Mmbtu, respectively. We have approximately 0.9&nbsp;million
barrels of oil and 2.2 Bcf of natural gas subject to CPRM contracts for 2003. The contracts for 2003 are at weighted average floor prices of $21.45 per barrel and $3.00 per Mmbtu and weighted average
ceiling prices of $23.08 per barrel and $6.50 per Mmbtu, respectively. These contracts represent our hedge and non-hedge positions. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
tables below provide details about the volumes and prices of all open CPRM commitments, hedge and non-hedge, as of March&nbsp;11, 2002: </FONT></P>

<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>&#151;</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="3%">&nbsp;</TD>

<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>

<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>18.86</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD COLSPAN=2><FONT SIZE=2>Three-way Collars (Mbbls) (2)(4)</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>2,067,000</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>1,095,000</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="54%"><FONT SIZE=2>Three-way average floor price</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>18.97</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>18.43</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="White" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="54%"><FONT SIZE=2>Average floor price per bbl</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>23.26</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>22.50</FONT></TD>
</TR>
<TR BGCOLOR="#CCEEFF" VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%">&nbsp;</TD>
<TD WIDTH="54%"><FONT SIZE=2>Average ceiling price per bbl</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>27.15</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>$</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="14%" ALIGN="RIGHT"><FONT SIZE=2>25.73</FONT></TD>
</TR>
</TABLE></DIV>
<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->

<HR NOSHADE ALIGN="LEFT" WIDTH="48">
<DL compact>
<DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(1)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>For
any particular swap sold transaction, the counterparty is required to make a payment to Westport in the event that the NYMEX Reference Price for any settlement period is less than
the swap price for such hedge, and Westport is required to make a payment to the counterparty in the event that the NYMEX Reference Price for any settlement period is greater than the swap price for
such hedge.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(2)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>For
any particular collar transaction, the counterparty is required to make a payment to Westport if the average NYMEX Reference Price for the reference period is below the floor
price for such transaction, and Westport is required to make payment to the counterparty if the average NYMEX Reference Price is above the ceiling price of such transaction.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(3)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Calls
or puts are sold under written option contracts in return for a premium received by Westport upon the initiation of the contract. Westport is required to make a payment to the
counterparty in the event that the NYMEX Reference price for any settlement period is greater than the price of the call sold, or less than the price of the put sold. Conversely, calls or puts bought
in return for Westport's payment of a premium require the counterparty to make a payment to Westport in the event that the NYMEX Reference Price on any settlement period is greater than the call price
or less than the put price.
<BR><BR></FONT></DD><DT style='margin-bottom:-11pt;'><FONT SIZE=2>(4)</FONT></DT><DD><FONT SIZE=2>Three
way collars are settled as described in footnote (2)&nbsp;above, with the following exception: if the NYMEX Reference Price falls below the three-way floor price,
the average floor price is reduced by the amount the NYMEX Reference Price is below the three-way floor price. For example, if the NYMEX Reference Price is $18.00 per bbl during the term
of the 2002 three-way collars, then the average floor price would be $22.29 per bbl. </FONT></DD></DL>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
designated that the interest rate swap contracts entered into in November&nbsp;2001 as fair value hedges of a portion of the 8<SUP>1</SUP>/<SMALL>4</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes and
8<SUP>7</SUP>/<SMALL>8</SMALL>% Senior Subordinated Notes. We did not designate the interest rate swap contract entered into in March&nbsp;1999 as a hedge.

discount. </FONT></P>

2001, we recorded other income of $5.0&nbsp;million related to the change in fair value of the non-hedge interest rate swap outstanding at December&nbsp;31, 2001 and
two other non-hedge interest rate swaps that settled prior to December&nbsp;31, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="dy1331_power_of_attorney"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_dy1331_2"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>POWER OF ATTORNEY    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The undersigned directors and officers of Westport Resources Corporation hereby constitute and appoint Donald D. Wolf and Barth E. Whitham, and each of them, with
the power to act without the other and with full power of substitution and resubstitution, our true and lawful attorneys-in-fact and agents with full power to execute in our
name and behalf in the capacities indicated below any and all amendments to this report and to file the same, with all exhibits and other documents relating thereto and hereby ratify and confirm all
that such attorneys-in-fact, or either of them, or their substitutes, may lawfully do or cause to be done by virtue hereof. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Pursuant
to the requirements of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, this report has been signed by the following persons in the capacities indicated on March&nbsp;19, 2002: </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="fb1331_report_of_independent_public_accountants"> </A>
<A NAME="toc_fb1331_1"> </A>
<BR></FONT><FONT SIZE=2><B>REPORT OF INDEPENDENT PUBLIC ACCOUNTANTS    <BR>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>To
Westport Resources Corporation: </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
have audited the accompanying consolidated balance sheets of Westport Resources Corporation (a Nevada corporation) and subsidiaries as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000, and the
related consolidated statements of operations, stockholders' equity and cash flows for each of the three&nbsp;years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. These financial statements are the
responsibility of the Company's management. Our responsibility is to express an opinion on these financial statements based on our audits. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
conducted our audits in accordance with auditing standards generally accepted in the United States. Those standards require that we plan and perform the audit to obtain reasonable
assurance about whether the financial statements are free of material misstatement. An audit includes examining, on a test basis, evidence supporting the amounts and disclosures in the financial
statements. An audit also includes assessing the accounting principles used and significant estimates made by management, as well as evaluating the overall financial statement presentation. We believe
that our audits provide a reasonable basis for our opinion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
our opinion, the financial statements referred to above present fairly, in all material respects, the financial position of Westport Resources Corporation and subsidiaries as of
December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000, and the results of their operations and their cash flows for each of the three&nbsp;years in the period ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, in conformity with
accounting principles generally accepted in the United States. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
explained in Notes 1and 4 to the consolidated financial statements, on January&nbsp;1, 2001, the Company changed its method of accounting for derivative instruments and hedging
activities. </FONT></P>

<!-- User-specified TAGGED TABLE -->
<TABLE WIDTH="76%" BORDER=0 CELLSPACING=0 CELLPADDING=0>
<TR VALIGN="TOP">
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="3%"><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;</FONT></TD>
<TD WIDTH="49%"><FONT SIZE=2>ARTHUR ANDERSEN LLP</FONT></TD>
</TR>

<!-- end of user-specified TAGGED TABLE -->


<P><FONT SIZE=2>Denver,
Colorado<BR>
March&nbsp;1, 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=66,EFW="2073669",CP="WESTPORT RESOURCES CORPORATION",DN="1",CHK=855761,FOLIO='F-6',FILE='DISK012:[02DEN1.02DEN1331]FE1331B.;9',USER='DTAYLOR',CD='18-MAR-2002;18:30' -->
